block.p: Foreign Minister Quits As Israeli Turmoil Grows Foreign Minister David Levy resigned over Prime Minister Ehud Barak's willingness to compromise with the Palestinians on Jerusalem. And four bills calling for new elections passed in the Knesset.

Donations Uproar in Japan The government of Prime Minister Yoshiro Mori was slammed by its second political scandal in a week when one of his top advisers admitted accepting millions of yen in questionable donations.

Foreign Minister Quits As Israeli Turmoil Grows Foreign Minister David Levy resigned over Prime Minister Ehud Barak's willingness to compromise with the Palestinians on Jerusalem. And four bills calling for new elections passed in the Knesset.

Donations Uproar in Japan The government of Prime Minister Yoshiro Mori was slammed by its second political scandal in a week when one of his top advisers admitted accepting millions of yen in questionable donations.

Deadly Rampages in Kashmir At least 93 people were slain in six massacres in the disputed area occupied by both India and Pakistan. Some people linked the killings to militant groups trying to sabotage a peace initiative.

Bickering Over Sect Leader Falun Gong followers in Hong Kong and the United States are squabbling over assertions by Belinda Pang, 37, who lives in the southern Chinese territory, that she is the true master of the spiritual movement, having taken over from its founder, Li Hongzhi, who has dropped from view.

Conference Omits Dalai Lama The Dalai Lama, spiritual leader of Tibetan Buddhism and winner of the Nobel Peace Prize in 1989, was omitted from the invitation list for the Millennium World Peace Summit of Religious and Spiritual Leaders next month, to avoid offending China.

Strike Paralyzes Zimbabwe Black union members and white business owners brought the country to a standstill as many workers stayed home and industrialists shut banks and businesses to protest farm invasions by black squatters.

South African Crime Data The minister of safety and security ordered an indefinite moratorium on the release of crime statistics, saying the system for collecting such information is unreliable. Critics questioned a decision that would keep the public in the dark about crime.
Russia Eyes Media Empire A senior Russian official said the government-controlled company Gazprom was in talks to acquire the media empire of Vladimir V. Gusinsky, a leading Kremlin critic.

G.O.P. Formalizes Ticket; Cheney Lashes Out at Gore The Republican party formally nominated Gov. George W. Bush for president. His running mate, Dick Cheney, delivered the most partisan attack of the convention, asserting that the election of Al Gore would perpetuate the failed policies of President Clinton.
Conservatives who would ordinarily prefer the convention have a harder edge are holding back out of an overriding desire to win in November.

Ford Hospitalized After Stroke Former President Gerald R. Ford, 87, was in the neurological intensive care unit of Philadelphia's Hahnemann University Hospital after having at least one small stroke over the past three days, doctors said. His condition was described as ''serious and improving,'' with the prognosis good for full recovery.

Clinton Delays Execution President Clinton delayed the execution of Juan Raul Garza, a drug dealer from Texas convicted of three murders seven years ago. Mr. Garza was scheduled to die on Saturday in what would have been the first federal execution in nearly 40 years. The delay lets Mr. Garza pursue new clemency procedures for inmates on federal death row.

California Power Drain California, coping with a heat wave that is searing the West, nearly ran out of power for the third straight day. Regulators ordered utilities to curtail supplies to big commercial users that have agreed to cut consumption in times of shortage. The crisis comes even though no power plants or transmission lines have failed and temperatures have been hot but not extraordinary.

Surge in Wildfires Prolonged hot and dry weather, especially in the West, has made this the worst year since the mid-1980's for wildfires around the country. So far this year, the National Interagency Fire Center in Boise, Idaho, has recorded 61,400 fires, which have burned nearly 3.6 million acres.

Verdict on Old Land Titles A Texas jury found that a New York lawyer, Gilbert Kerlin, defrauded hundreds of relatives of a 19th-century priest more than six decades ago and now owes them millions of dollars in oil royalties and interest.

Police Arrest 2 Suspects In Fatal Stabbing of Student The police have charged David Jamison, 27, and Felix Rodriguez, 20, with murdering and robbing Amy Watkins, a Hunter graduate student stabbed to death on a Brooklyn street last year.

Subway Fires Disrupt 4 Lines Two underground electrical fires in downtown Brooklyn forced the closing of parts of four of the city's busiest subway lines -- the 2, 3, 4 and 5 -- just as the evening rush began.

Death Penalty Law Upheld The New Jersey Supreme Court upheld the state's death penalty review process, but also found it ''inherently unreliable'' in assessing whether race plays a role in determining who is prosecuted for a capital crime and sentenced to death.
Shlomo Halberstam The grand rabbi, a Holocaust survivor whose gentle charisma nurtured the exuberant postwar rebirth of the Bobov Hasidic sect in Brooklyn and around the world, was 92.

Guidance on Ethics The American Association of Museums, responding to criticism over financing of the ''Sensation'' exhibition at the Brooklyn Museum of Art, adopted guidelines on how museums should oversee displays of art borrowed from private collections.
Recycling of Medical Devices The F.D.A. will begin requiring that recycled medical devices originally intended to be used only once meet the same regulatory standards that they did when manufactured.
Study on Steroid Inhalers Asthma sufferers who regularly use steroid inhalers to ease their breathing problems also lower their risk of dying from the disease.
Advance in Cholera Treatment The genome of the bacterium that causes cholera has been decoded by the Institute for Genomic Research in Rockville, Md., paving the way for better vaccines and drugs.

G.M. Challenge to Ford General Motors declared that no matter how much Ford improved the energy efficiency of its sport utility vehicles by 2005, G.M.'s sport utilities would average even more miles to the gallon by then.
Stocks March Mostly in Place The Nasdaq slipped 27.06 points, to 3,658.46, but the Dow rose 80.58 points, to 10,687.53, and the S.& P. 500 edged up 0.60 of a point, to 1,438.70.
Stars' Adviser Pleads Guilty Dana C. Giacchetto, the money manager whose Cassandra Group favored celebrities and artists, pleaded guilty to fraud and admitted to misappropriating clients' money.

Setback for Creationists Kansas voters rejected three state school board candidates who supported the removal of evolution from state science standards. The vote made it all but certain that the decision would be overturned.
Editorials: Mr. Bush's next speech; an ugly move by big tobacco; Senator Torricelli retreats; Verlyn Klinkenborg on the damp July.
